channel.title: Computahh Science
channel.description:
Anyone here (in the UK) completed or done a year of the course?
I want to know what you really learn in it. For example, most universities say they do object oriented programming with Java as one module but don't say how advanced it goes.
Is anyone finding it hard/easy?

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

You learn algorithms/languages/theorems/etc. It really depends on the school, but in most cases you learn as much as you can about computing.

ps, spell it correctly; it makes you look like an idiot.

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Here you go, I suppose it won’t hurt to link you to the degree course outlines that my university provides.
http://www.newcastle.edu.au/program/10177.html

I forgot to mention things like compiler design. I don’t know how much similarity there would be between the compulsory courses completed in a British degree and the compulsory courses completed in an Australian one, but having quickly scanned over it I can say that it at least seems bullshit-free.

EDIT: I do have a question of my own that is sort of relevant to this topic (and certainly not worth its own topic) for anyone studying in Britain.
What is the quality of teaching there like? Mediocre? Reasonable? Engaging?
I’ve had some really horrible lecturers myself, and that’s something I’m curious about. It’s no secret that my university is pretty shit in many respects, so maybe that’s the real issue here (surely Australian universities don’t get much worse than Newcastle uni)

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

he should be spared that kind of thing if he does computing science at any decent uni in the uk

for example UEA where i was looking at before i became a dropout bum the first year is something like 1/3 programming, 1/3 “math related to comp sci” and 1/3 like history and abstract theory stuff, no IT-related stuff at all

thats if you do prue comp sci though, theres a lot of comp sci + ____ courses for people who want to go into more specialised careers (game dev for example), comp sci + business, etc

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

My discrete maths course contained the following:

1. Elementary set theory 2. Enumeration techniques 3. Graph theory 4. Elementary probability theory 5. Logic and proofs 6. Relations 7. Introduction to codes

The two courses that I won’t be doing contain the following:

First course:

1. Differentiation 2. Optimization 3. Riemann integral 4. Exponential, logarithmic, and hyperbolic and trigonometric functions 5. Techniques of integration 6. Complex numbers 7. Polar coordinates 8. Vectors, dot and cross products 9. Lines and planes 10. Systems of equations 11. Geometry of curves.

Second course:

1. sequences, series and approximation

  1. introduction to functions of more than one variable and partial differentiation

  2. elementary differential equations and applications

  3. linear equations and matrices

  4. eigenvectors and eigenvalues and applications

For the record, IT does include some rather dry subjects that do involve Microsoft products (or comparable open source products :P). One particular subject covered databases and objects/entities; for some reason we had to make a game using ‘Gamemaker’ (a rather shitty little application that can be used to make sprite-based games).
With any luck you’ll be spared from that kind of thing, but you never know.
The compulsory courses can be quite bad, and sometimes they don’t have any value at all - it begs the question: why do they exist?

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

Could you give me an example of an algorithm or the logic? I can’t really picture in my head what ‘logic’ really is as a mathematical topic.

I know this is all completely abstract, but it’s better than knowing nothing.

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

obviously i cant say what will be in your module, but the a-level discrete maths module i did basically dealt with logic, graphs, algorithms, that kind of thing. a* and dijkstra’s etc. etc.

“math that is applicable to computer science” is a pretty good broad explanation of it

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

Wow that sounds awesome, I was afraid computer science could be too much like IT and I’d end up learning the advanced features of microsoft word and being able to define the term array.

What you said ties in with the prospectuses, only they give me vague titles and don’t say exactly what is involved in that module.

I have to do a discrete maths module because I don’t have the A-Level, but again they don’t describe exactly what’s in that module. If you’ve done it, could you give me a quick overview on what was involved?

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I’m doing IT at university and, at my university at least, there’s a lot of crossover between computer science and IT.
With that said though I’m sure that the advice/insight I can offer is at least partially applicable in Britain.

My Java-specific course was rather mundane, elementary programming at best. However it was an entry level course intended to get people on their feet and using a programming language.
IT here only has one compulsory maths subject (discrete maths) which covers things such as graph theory, probability theory and set theory (not directly related to programming by any stretch and applicable in a wide variety of fields beyond IT and computer science, but the theory can be, and probably often is, used in real-world programming projects).
Computer science has 3 maths courses (one being discrete maths, and the other two sort of continue on from high school maths). I haven’t done the other two courses (thank christ) because I don’t have to, so I can’t comment on them.

I’ve also covered a C+±specific programming course (a follow on course from the Java course to cover lower level concepts such as pointers, pointer arithmetic, templates and the STL, and use of other standard C/C++ header files). It also brought data structures into the mix (lists, queues, deques, stacks, maps, sets).

The more useful stuff at my university, and many others, obviously comes later on. I’m doing a distributed computing course at the moment which covers things such as client-server architecture, use of tomcat (java specific - I’d debate the appropriateness of using language-specific education at university, but whatever), distributed security/sychronization/etc.
I don’t doubt that you’d at least have the opportunity to take part in some sort of security course which would cover things such as key and identify management, one way hash functions, public-private key encryption, password storage and so on, along with approaches to implementation of these things in an application (for example where the security should take place - at the client end, at the server front-end, at the server back-end (the database perhaps, to validate any input before adding it to the db), or from endpoint to endpoint).

I suppose what really needs to be pointed out is the biggest difference between IT and computer science.
Computer science is heavily tied in with algorithmics, mathematical aspects and low level aspects of computing, and the more intrinsic details - namely the precise nature of program execution, process scheduling and management and so on. Frankly some of it is beyond me because I don’t do some of the CPU science courses.

Hope I’ve helped.

Read full topic

item.title: Computahh Science
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“inertia, post:5, topic:304523”]Has anyone actually done the course?[/quote]It depends on the university. Most of it is problem solving. In that regard, the language is (sortof) redundant. Therefore, different places teach different languages.

As for the difficulty level, it also depends on the kinds of problem you will have to solve. Either way, you will have to read a lot, be it in notes or on the computer, and it is no way an easy course.

Read full topic
